moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. b3 e6 3. Bb2 d5 4. a3: a3 is important to keep the B from landing on b4.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Nf3 Be7 6. e3 O-O 7. Bd3 h6: Black is apparently planning a pawn assault.
moves.9. O-O f5 10. Ne5 Rf6 11. f4 Nxe5: Black exchanges off my best piece.
I think Black might have done better to maintain the tension in the center.  This allows me to undouble my pawns.
moves.18... Bxd2 19. Bxf5 exf5: Now my e5 pawn is a passer.
moves.20. Qxd2 b6 21. c5: Trying to open the file for my R.  I have an edge in development that I will try to exploit.
moves.21... Qg5 22. Qxg5: Exchanging Qs makes my job easier, in my opinion, because it reduces Black's attacking chances.
moves.22... Rxg5 23. c6: Now the c pawn is passed also.
moves.23... Ba6 24. Rf2 Rc8 25. a4: Either I can block his B with b4, b5 or he will have to block his own B in with b4.
moves.25... Rc7 26. Ba3 Rg6 27. Bd6: Now I can push his R off the c7 square.
moves.27... Rf7 28. Rf4 Bc8 29. c7: Black's pieces are now quite tied down and have limited mobility.
moves.29... Rd7: This R move allows the f pawn to hang.
moves.30. Rc6 Kf7 31. Rxf5+ Ke6 32. Rf4 Bb7: Allowing the pawn to promote, which will give me a decisive material advantage.
moves.33. c8=Q Bxc8 34. Rxc8 Rb7 35. Rff8: My Rs dominate the open files.
